evidence.evidence_text: 773 burial mounds documented during pedestrian survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria (2009-2011)
evidence.verbatim_quote: In this study we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria

evidence.evidence_text: First CNN run: F1 score of 0.87 reported by the model
evidence.verbatim_quote: After image augmentation, the model reported good learning and model fit (F1 5 0.87)

evidence.evidence_text: First run validation: 19 of 148 tagged tiles (12.8%) contained actual mounds
evidence.verbatim_quote: Nevertheless, only 19 out of 148 tiles (12.8%) tagged by the model with at least a 60% chance of having a mound actually contained one

evidence.evidence_text: First run: 129 of 148 tiles (87.1%) were false positives
evidence.verbatim_quote: Some 129 of the tagged tiles (87.1%) were false positives

evidence.evidence_text: First run: 38 of 773 mounds (4.9%) detected; 735 undetected; false negative rate 95.3%
evidence.verbatim_quote: The 19 true-positive tiles contained 38 mounds (1–9 mounds per tile), out of 773 in the study area (4.9%), while the remaining 735 mounds went undetected... a false negative rate of 95.3%

evidence.evidence_text: Second CNN run: F1 score of 0.62 reported by the model
evidence.verbatim_quote: The second model's performance declined to an F1 score of 0.62

evidence.evidence_text: Second run validation: 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%) detected; 752 (97.3%) undetected
evidence.verbatim_quote: Validation revealed that only 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%) were detected, while 752 mounds (97.3%) remained undetected

evidence.evidence_text: Second run: 15 of 288 tiles (5.2%) were true positives; 273 (94.8%) were false positives
evidence.verbatim_quote: Only 15 of these 288 tiles (5.2%), however, were true positives, containing the 21 detected mounds... The remaining 273 of 288 tiles were false positives (94.8%)

evidence.evidence_text: Development of CNN model required approximately 135 person-hours
evidence.verbatim_quote: Developing our CNN model required approximately 135 person-hours from conceptualisation and experiments to validation and documentation

evidence.evidence_text: Model trained using ResNet-50 pre-trained CNN with TensorFlow 2 in Python
evidence.verbatim_quote: After some preliminary experimentation with a range of different pre-trained models, we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data... The model was deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python
The ratio of positive to negative training data was approximately 1:2 (32%–68%)

evidence.evidence_text: First run used all 773 mounds for training; second run used 249 clearly visible mounds
evidence.verbatim_quote: In the 2021 run of the model, we used all 773 cutouts for training regardless of what was visible in the satellite image. In the 2022 run, we selected 249 cutouts where a mound was discernible with the naked eye

evidence.evidence_text: Literature review: 44 of 70 papers (63%) fail to mention negative aspects of AI/ML approaches
evidence.verbatim_quote: Considering the 70 papers from the Web of Science mentioned above, 44 abstracts (63%) fail to mention any negative aspects of AI/ML approaches at all

evidence.evidence_text: Only 4 papers (6%) discuss attempts that ended in partial or complete failure
evidence.verbatim_quote: Only 15 papers include specific or sustained critiques of ML approaches. Of those 15, seven (10% of the corpus) present qualified successes, while four (6%) discuss attempts to deploy ML that ended in partial or complete failures

evidence.evidence_text: Three public GitHub repositories contain all code for data processing and analysis
evidence.verbatim_quote: Data processing and analysis was performed using R and Python and the scripts are available in public repositories: (1) Training data preparation and CNN prediction validation can be found in https://github.com/adivea/cnn-testing (2) 2021 CNN classifier training and mound prediction is implemented in https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/burial-mounds (3) 2022 CNN classifier training and mound prediction is implemented in https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/MoundDetection

evidence.evidence_text: IKONOS satellite imagery at 1m panchromatic and 4m multispectral resolution covering 600 sq km
evidence.verbatim_quote: The satellite imagery used in this study consists of two IKONOS scenes covering 600 sq km delivered in geoTIFF format... The scenes included a panchromatic band at 1 m resolution and a multispectral image (RGBNIR) at 4 m resolution

evidence.evidence_text: AI/ML publications for archaeological remote sensing reached 17% of total in 2023, indicating adoption approaching 'crossing the chasm'
evidence.verbatim_quote: These 21 publications represent about 17% of the 2023 total (n=125) for archaeological remote sensing... If publication counts are used a proxy for research, this 17% figure indicates that AI/ML is on the cusp of 'crossing the chasm'

claims.claim_text: The study tests transfer learning CNN approaches for detecting burial mounds in high-resolution satellite imagery against a ground-truthed dataset of 773 field-verified mounds
claims.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery... we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey

claims.claim_text: External validation against independent field data is essential for evaluating CNN model performance in archaeological prospection
claims.verbatim_quote: The model has detected incidental features rather than the mounds themselves, making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.claim_text: The dataset of 773 field-verified burial mounds provides robust ground truth for validating ML predictions
claims.verbatim_quote: In this study we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria... This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey

claims.claim_text: The pre-trained ResNet-50 CNN with transfer learning approach was selected based on preliminary experimentation showing it performed best for this data
claims.verbatim_quote: After some preliminary experimentation with a range of different pre-trained models, we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data

claims.claim_text: Despite reporting a good F1 score (0.87), the first CNN model failed to accurately detect burial mounds when validated against field data
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena

claims.claim_text: Self-reported ML metrics (F1 scores) are misleadingly high and do not reflect actual model performance in detecting archaeological features
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.claim_text: The second model (trained on curated, highly visible mounds) performed worse than the first model (trained on all mounds)
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds (rather than all mounds) performed worse

claims.claim_text: Additional curation of training data did not improve and actually worsened model performance
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful than the first; the false positives and false negatives increased and fewer mounds were detected

claims.claim_text: The CNN model development required approximately 135 person-hours of work, representing significant resource investment
claims.verbatim_quote: Development of the model, meanwhile, required approximately 135 person-hours of work

claims.claim_text: Given the results and resource investment, manual approaches (expert inspection or crowdsourcing) would likely be more efficient for this application
claims.verbatim_quote: In our case, given the size of our study area and the number of features it likely contains, manual approaches like visual inspection by experts or crowdsourcing to volunteers would probably be more efficient

claims.claim_text: The CNN detected incidental background features (edges of forests, roads, shorelines) rather than the target mound features
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, the model seemed to select bright lines and edges (forest, roads), rather than round shapes more likely to represent mounds

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNN models with low-touch training struggle when detecting varied features in heterogeneous landscapes with confounding natural and modern features
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features of different sizes within a heterogeneous landscape that contains confounding natural and modern features

claims.claim_text: The ML-for-archaeology literature exhibits publication bias, with overwhelmingly positive reporting and few discussions of failures or challenges
claims.verbatim_quote: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success

claims.claim_text: This paper serves as a necessary counterbalance and cautionary tale for potential adopters of ML technology in archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the failure of a good-faith attempt to utilise these approaches as a counterbalance and cautionary tale to potential adopters of the technology

claims.claim_text: Complete code transparency is provided through three public GitHub repositories covering all data processing and analysis
claims.verbatim_quote: Data processing and analysis was performed using R and Python and the scripts are available in public repositories

claims.claim_text: AI/ML approaches to archaeological remote sensing are approaching mainstream adoption ('crossing the chasm'), making critical assessment increasingly important
claims.verbatim_quote: If publication counts are used a proxy for research, this 17% figure indicates that AI/ML is on the cusp of 'crossing the chasm' separating 'innovators' and 'early adopters' (together 16% of the population) from the 'early majority'

implicit_arguments.argument_text: External field validation is more reliable than self-reported ML metrics for assessing actual model performance
trigger_text: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The stark contrast between reported F1 scores (0.87, 0.62) and actual detection rates (4.9%, 2.7%) implies that field validation reveals ground truth that self-reported metrics cannot capture.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Transfer learning assumptions about generalisation from pre-trained models may not hold for archaeological applications with heterogeneous targets
trigger_text: Transfer learning assumes that large, complex models can be pre-trained using data from one domain, then fine-tuned for a specific task in another domain

Our outcomes indicate that even an advanced pre-trained model... is likely to fail when asked to detect somewhat variable features against very heterogeneous backgrounds with only a low-touch approach to training
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper tests the transfer learning assumption and demonstrates its limitations for varied archaeological features, implying that standard ML assumptions may not transfer to HASS domains with complex, variable targets.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Publication bias in ML-for-archaeology literature creates unrealistic expectations for practitioners
trigger_text: The overwhelmingly positive tone of these papers likely indicates a certain degree of 'publication bias'
Early-majority adopters may find ML difficult to implement effectively in real-life scenarios
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: By connecting publication bias to adoption challenges, the paper implies that the biased literature creates a gap between expected and actual outcomes for new adopters.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Reporting time-on-task and resource requirements is essential for enabling informed decisions about ML approaches
trigger_text: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
Very few projects, furthermore, report the time and resources invested in their approach
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: By emphasising the rarity of resource reporting and explicitly providing it, the authors imply this information is necessary for practitioners to make cost-benefit decisions.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Negative results have scientific value equal to or greater than positive results in advancing methodological understanding
trigger_text: This paper offers a cautionary tale about the challenges, limitations, and demands of ML applied to archaeological prospection
it is important to document unsuccessful attempts to apply ML techniques to archaeological remote sensing
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The explicit framing of failure as valuable contribution implies an assumption that negative results advance knowledge by helping others avoid similar pitfalls.

research_designs.design_text: Hypothesis-testing design to evaluate whether pre-trained CNN with transfer learning can effectively detect burial mounds in satellite imagery
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery. We developed a pre-trained CNN that was further trained using two datasets

research_designs.design_text: Comparative design testing two training data strategies: all mounds vs. visually discernible mounds only
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We first used an indiscriminate collection of burial mounds, regardless of their visibility in the satellite imagery. We next used only those mounds that we deemed easily discernible in the satellite imagery

research_designs.design_text: External validation design using independent field-collected ground truth data to assess model predictions
research_designs.verbatim_quote: After this training, we applied the models to our imagery and validated results using our field data

methods.method_text: Transfer learning using pre-trained ResNet-50 CNN for image classification
methods.verbatim_quote: Rather than training our own model from scratch, we used a pre-trained CNN, a technique known as transfer learning... we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data

methods.method_text: Systematic pedestrian survey for ground truth data collection
methods.verbatim_quote: This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey. TRAP survey identified many 0.5–20 m high (5–100 m diameter) conical features in the landscape as burial mounds

methods.method_text: Manual validation of CNN predictions against ground-truthed mound locations
methods.verbatim_quote: After the initial performance evaluation, we manually validated model performance. To do so, we verified mound predictions using points marking ground-truthed mounds in the 85 sq km section of the satellite image

methods.method_text: Systematic literature review of AI/ML publications in archaeological remote sensing
methods.verbatim_quote: Figure 2 displays the annual publication count in each of the past 10 years (n=70; research articles and conference papers plus one preprint) in Web of Science for 'topic' including 'archaeology', and 'remote sensing or satellite image', and 'machine learning or artificial intelligence'

protocols.protocol_text: Training data preparation: 150x150m cutouts generated from mound GPS points, MOUND/NOT MOUND classification, image augmentation (vertical/horizontal flip, random rotation), 70:20:10 split for training/validation/test
protocols.verbatim_quote: Mound points taken during fieldwork were used as centroids for the generation of 150 x 150 m square polygons... This process yielded 773 MOUND cutouts... After processing, cutouts were divided into training, validation, and test sets following a 70:20:10 ratio

protocols.protocol_text: CNN model deployment using TensorFlow 2 in Python with data augmentation to counter overfitting
protocols.verbatim_quote: The model was deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python... In order to counter this overfitting, we used proven data augmentation techniques to constrain model performance

protocols.protocol_text: Field recording of mounds with GPS coordinates, height, diameter, surface/surrounding land use, and preservation status using Likert scale and Wildesen classification
protocols.verbatim_quote: Each mound was recorded with a GPS point, height, diameter, and surface and surrounding land use, as well as preservation status using Likert scale and Wildesen (1982) classification

protocols.protocol_text: Validation protocol: select predictions >0.599 probability, generate 150m square polygons, intersect with ground-truthed mound points, classify as true positive/false positive/false negative
protocols.verbatim_quote: We selected prediction records whose mound-probability exceeded 0.599 and used the coordinates to generate square polygons of 150 m side. We intersected these polygons with the points marking ground-truthed mounds. Mounds that fell inside the tiles were considered successfully detected (true positives). Mounds outside the flagged tiles were missed by the model (false negatives). Tiles flagged by the model that did not contain mounds constituted false positives

protocols.protocol_text: Web of Science search for topic terms 'archaeology' AND 'remote sensing or satellite image' AND 'machine learning or artificial intelligence', manually reviewed to eliminate irrelevant publications
protocols.verbatim_quote: in Web of Science for 'topic' including 'archaeology', and 'remote sensing or satellite image', and 'machine learning or artificial intelligence' (and variations thereof), manually reviewed to eliminate any publications that did not in fact discuss archaeology or ML/AI

repositories.name: cnn-testing
repositories.description: Training data preparation and CNN prediction validation

repositories.name: burial-mounds
repositories.description: 2021 CNN classifier training and mound prediction

repositories.name: MoundDetection
repositories.description: 2022 CNN classifier training and mound prediction

machine_actionability.rationale: Complete code available in public repositories with clear descriptions, but no formal environment specification (requirements.txt, Docker) provided

data_availability.description: Field data (773 mounds) collected by TRAP project; satellite imagery acquired through GeoEye Foundation grant (commercial, not shareable)

machine_actionability.rationale: Commercial satellite imagery cannot be redistributed; field data reference-only through published reports

author_contributions.details: Team described: two digital archaeologists, ML specialist with heritage experience, junior developer
